start.brief_description: England, early 18th century. The close relationship between Queen Anne and Sarah Churchill is threatened by the arrival of Sarah’s cousin, Abigail Hill, resulting in a bitter rivalry between the two cousins to be the Queen’s favourite.

end.title: Tekken
end.brief_description:
Seventeen of the world’s deadliest fighters, explosive martial arts moves and savage special attacks. All brought to life by super smooth animation running at a TV scorching 50 frames per second (Original description).

Tekken is the first game in the Tekken series. It was released in arcades on December 9, 1994 in Japan, and on December 11, 1994 in Europe and North America. It was then ported to the Sony PlayStation on March 31, 1995 in Japan, November 7, 1995 in Europe, and on November 8, 1995 in North America. The game was met with many positive reviews.

constellations_other.name: Fish-eyes and fun times
constellations_other.description: This Constellation starts with The Favourite and ends up at Rambo, and was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

links.description: Leonardo NoOscaro finally got his Oscar for The Revenant, which featured a brutal scene of his character being mauled by a bear. Tekken players could sympathise with him since the fighting game also contains a playable bear as one of its characters.

end.title: Wake in Fright
end.creator_credit: Ron Williams, George Willoughby, Group W, Dennis Gentle and Evan Jones
end.brief_description: Wake in Fright is the story of John Grant, a bonded teacher who arrives in the rough outback mining town of Bundanyabba planning to stay overnight before catching the plane to Sydney, but as one night stretches into several he plunges headlong into his own destruction.

constellations_other.name: Fish-eyes and fun times
constellations_other.description: This Constellation starts with The Favourite and ends up at Rambo, and was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

links.description: The Tekken series also has a playable kangaroo. While its kangaroo is alive and well, Wake in Fright features a controversial scene of real kangaroos being shot by real hunters. Animal rights groups endorsed the scene, hoping it would inspire banning roo hunting.

end.title: First Blood
end.creator_credit: Buzz Feitshans
end.brief_description: When former Green Beret John Rambo is harassed by local law enforcement and arrested for vagrancy, the Vietnam vet snaps, runs for the hills and rat-a-tat-tats his way into the action-movie hall of fame. Hounded by a relentless sheriff, Rambo employs heavy-handed guerilla tactics to shake the cops off his tail.

constellations_other.name: Fish-eyes and fun times
constellations_other.description: This Constellation starts with The Favourite and ends up at Rambo, and was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

links.description: “We ain’t huntin’ him, he’s huntin’ us!” Wake in Fright director Ted Kotcheff went all-in on hunting when he directed the first film in the Rambo series, which featured Sly Stallone as a former Green Beret using guerilla tactics to outwit red necks.

results.name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred
results.description: The accessibility and portability of cameras has had a big impact on how we see ourselves and the world. As camera technology continues to evolve, so do our ways of seeing, with the line between reality and fiction disappearing.

key_work.title: Film cameras
key_work.brief_description: The home-movie market took off after World War II. Enthusiasts across the world began to document their lives with a series of small, easy-to-use home-movie cameras that shot on 8mm and 16mm film, like the Bolex H16 camera.

constellations_primary.name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred
constellations_primary.description: The accessibility and portability of cameras has had a big impact on how we see ourselves and the world. As camera technology continues to evolve, so do our ways of seeing, with the line between reality and fiction disappearing.

start.title: Me at the Zoo
start.brief_description: Me at the zoo is the first video that was uploaded to YouTube. It was uploaded on April 23, 2005 at 20:27:12 PDT by the site’s co-founder Jawed Karim, with the username “jawed” and recorded by his high school friend Yakov Lapitsky. He created a YouTube account on the same day. - Wikipedia

constellations_other.name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred
constellations_other.description: The accessibility and portability of cameras has had a big impact on how we see ourselves and the world. As camera technology continues to evolve, so do our ways of seeing, with the line between reality and fiction disappearing.

end.title: The Blair Witch Project
end.creator_credit: Gregg Hale and Robin Cowie
end.brief_description: In October of 1994 three student filmmakers disappeared in the woods near Burkittsville, Maryland, while shooting a documentary. A year later their footage was found.

constellations_other.name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred
constellations_other.description: The accessibility and portability of cameras has had a big impact on how we see ourselves and the world. As camera technology continues to evolve, so do our ways of seeing, with the line between reality and fiction disappearing.

constellations_other.name: Found footage and the first camcorder
constellations_other.description: Amateur filmmakers turned the camera on their own lives when camcorders like the Sony Betamovie BMC-100P came on the market. The style of footage filmed on camcorders has inspired many fictional films, particularly in the horror genre.

constellations_other.name: Making home movies
constellations_other.description: Home movies have inspired the form and plots of narrative cinema.

recommendations.quote: Not only did The Blair Witch Project scare up $248.6 million USD at the box office, it also created the first viral marketing campaign (which led many people to believe it was true) and ushered in the era of hand-held doco-style found footage horror films.

links.description: YouTube was the by-product of accessible and affordable video cameras, as well as the popularity of DIY video. Likewise, the low-fi, found film phenomenon was an unexpected side effect of the 90s amateur movie making equipment, exemplified by The Blair Witch Project.

start.title: Taxi
start.brief_description: A yellow cab is driving through the vibrant and colourful streets of Tehran. Very diverse passengers enter the taxi, each candidly expressing their views while being interviewed by the driver who is no one else but the director Jafar Panahi himself. His camera placed on the dashboard of his mobile film studio captures the spirit of Iranian society through this comedic and dramatic drive…

end.creator_credit: Emily Moran, Adam Sidman, Natalie Qasabian, Sev Ohanian and Timur Bekmambetov

video_links.name: SEARCHING - Official International Trailer - In Cinemas September 2018

end.brief_description: After David Kim’s 16-year-old daughter goes missing, a local investigation is opened and a detective is assigned to the case. But 37 hours later and without a single lead, David decides to search the one place no one has looked yet, where all secrets are kept today: his daughter’s laptop.

constellations_other.name: Screen story searching
constellations_other.description: Cinema, smartphones and sensuality collide in this intriguing Constellation that takes a distinctly different path.

links.description: Searching uses footage filmed entirely from built-in computer cameras, screen captures and smart phones. Reflecting our times and lack of privacy left in the world dominated by cameras and digital platforms to share footage.

constellations_other.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

links.description: Tangerine is short entirely on an iPhone 5s and captures the life of a transgender sex worker using the ‘home made’ look of the cinematography to communicate the harsh reality, as well as the energy, of life on the streets.

key_work.brief_description: Splitting Time explores the contribution of early photographers to the development of the moving image.

start.title: A Trip to the Moon
start.brief_description: Professor Barbenfouillis and five of his colleagues from the Academy of Astronomy travel to the Moon aboard a rocket propelled by a giant cannon. Once on the lunar surface, the bold explorers face the many perils hidden in the caves of the mysterious satellite.

end.title: Hugo
end.creator_credit: Graham King, Johnny Depp, Martin Scorsese and Tim Headington
end.headline_credit: France, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2011
end.brief_description: Orphaned except for an uncle, Hugo Cabret lives in the walls of a train station in 1930s Paris. His job is to oil and maintain the station’s clocks, but he’s more interested in protecting a broken automaton and notebook left to him by his late father.

constellations_other.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_other.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

constellations_other.name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge
constellations_other.description: A focus on the discovery, inspiration and innovation at the heart of moving image history

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

links.description: Méliès’s work inspired Martin Scorsese to create Hugo as a homage to Méliès and a celebration of the wonder of early filmmaking.

video_links.name: The Mandalorian | Official Trailer | Disney+ | Streaming Nov. 12
The Mandalorian | Season 2 Official Trailer | Disney+
The Mandalorian | Official Trailer 2 | Disney+ | Streaming Nov. 12

start.brief_description: After the fall of the Galactic Empire, lawlessness has spread throughout the galaxy. A lone gunfighter makes his way through the outer reaches, earning his keep as a bounty hunter.

constellations_other.name: Action, emotion and videogames

constellations_other.name: Sound and cinema
constellations_other.description: Beginning with one of the first films to be screened at the Palais (a Melbourne cinema with its own outstanding resident orchestra) the constellation celebrates sound as an integral part of the connection between moving image work and audience.

constellations_other.name: Aquaman VFX
constellations_other.description: As well as becoming a global box-office sensation, Aquaman (2018) featured groundbreaking visual effects from Australian companies such as Method Studios.

end.title: King Kong
end.creator_credit: Ernest B. Schoedsack, Merian C. Cooper, Walter Daniels and Willis H. O'Brien
end.brief_description: Adventurous filmmaker, Carl Denham, sets out to produce a motion picture unlike anything the world has seen before. Alongside his leading lady Ann Darrow and his first mate Jack Driscoll, they arrive on an island and discover a legendary creature said to be neither beast nor man. Denham captures the monster to displayed on Broadway as Kong, the eighth wonder of the world.

constellations_other.name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge
constellations_other.description: A focus on the discovery, inspiration and innovation at the heart of moving image history

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

constellations_other.name: MoCaps and rotos
constellations_other.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

links.description: Similar to each new Star Wars narrative, the numerous versions of King Kong have employed special and visual effects that build on a history of creation. The original movie is renowned for complex stop motion, in-camera effects and rear projection.

start.brief_description: Monkeyshines, No. 1 was shot by William K. L. Dickson and William Heise for the Edison labs. The series were filmed in the format of the Kinetoscope, and are believed to be the first films shot in the United States.

links.description: By breaking down movement into increments of time, Muybridge provided a new understanding of movement. His photographs formed a moving image sequence, an innovation that inspired the Edison Manufacturing Company’s Kinetoscope projector and their early experiments in film called Monkeyshines.

results.name: A handheld aesthetic
results.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

key_work.title: Sony Handycam DCR-SX65
key_work.brief_description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 debuted in 1985 and while other models from the era have been discontinued, it’s been made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but camcorders like this have captured footage that has social and political ramifications.

start.title: The Celebration
start.brief_description: A grandiose party to celebrate a sixtieth birthday unleashes a family drama with all the lies that conceal horrendous secrets. The eldest son, Christian, stages a showdown with the popular pater familias; his provocative, moving after-dinner speech dislodges all the masks, which finally fall completely as the father-son conflict intensifies and the bewildered guests look on.

end.brief_description: With his first Dogma-95 film director Lars von Trier opens up a completely new film platform. With a mix of home-video and documentary styles the film tells the story of a group of young people who have decided to get to know their “inner-idiots” and thus not only facing and breaking their outer appearance but also their inner.

constellations_other.name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred

start.title: Bush Mechanics
start.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

links.description: Young men from Yuendumu travel through country, facing challenges with zany good humour and keeping their cars going with inventive bush repair techniques. Malcolm also features whacky ingenuity and re-purposed vehicles including a car that divides in half.

links.description: Malcolm’s childlike perspective is highlighted through the playful discordance of compositions by the Penguin Cafe Orchestra, including Perpetuum Mobile. In Mary and Max, this repetitious piece communicates the main characters’ innocent dreams for a better life.

end.title: Bush Mechanics animation (2015)
end.brief_description: In the central Australian desert, four Warlpiri men travel to visit a powerful elder at a remote outstation. On the road they must overcome mechanical mishaps and the trickery of a mischievous spirit. It will take all of their bush ingenuity to keep their car running and themselves alive.

links.description: The hand-made claymation technique used in Mary and Max foregrounds the process of creation in a very human way making it the perfect medium for animating the improvised and do-it-yourself creativity of the Bush Mechanics.

end.title: Aboriginal Rules (2006)
end.brief_description: Independently funded 55 minute documentary produced in 2006 by Warlpiri Media Association. Directed by Liam Campbell and co-directed by Francis Jupurrurla Kelly and Neil Jupurrurla White, Aboriginal Rules follows the Yuendumu Magpies AFL team for a year. Over that time we see the highs and lows of their aspiration to win the Central Australia Football League Grand Final. We also get an insight into the challenges of young Aboriginal men growing up on settlements.

links.description: The Bush Mechanics series and more recent claymation are PAW media productions, a company specialising in producing media in language. PAW media’s documentary, Aboriginal Rules, focuses on the Yuendumu footy team that featured in the Bush Mechanics episode ‘The Chase’.

end.title: The Marngrook Footy Show
end.brief_description:
The Marngrook Footy Show was a sport panel show broadcast in Australia. Debuting in 2007, the show aired on NITV, and was previously simulcast on Channel 31 Melbourne.

Between 2011 and 2012, the program was broadcast on ABC2, and was shown live in 2012, but had its time-slot moved several times. From 2013 the show is produced by Toombak Indigenous Productions and broadcast on NITV/SBS.[1] The show is produced at the Burwood campus of Deakin University in its professional-standard television studio.

The show was axed in October 2019 after 12 years.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: Football is an important part of many Aboriginal communities and relates to marngrook, a traditional Indigenous football game. The Marngrook Footy Show is a sports entertainment panel show that offers an Indigenous perspective on the Australian Football League (AFL).

results.name: Timeless early animation
results.description: This Constellation traces the inspirations and evolution of the Cuphead animation technique and franchise back to the early 20th century and beyond.

key_work.title: Cuphead: Inspiration from the Inkwell
key_work.brief_description: The charming and cheeky animated characters of Studio MDHR’s Cuphead videogame spring into action in this contemporary incarnation of the popular 19th century invention, the zoetrope.

constellations_primary.name: Timeless early animation

constellations_other.name: Binary images
constellations_other.description: The interiors in Kalonica's Apartment (2021) are rendered in just two colours: white and blue. Like black and white film, this monochromatic art style was first employed due to technological constraints. Many contemporary filmmakers and videogame developers have revisited older techniques like these for artistic effect.

key_work.title: The first home console
key_work.brief_description: In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

results.name: Directions of storytelling
results.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

key_work.title: European hand-painted panoramic magic lantern slides
key_work.brief_description: Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

links.description: Cinematographer Robert Yeoman incorporated whip pans into Wes Anderson’s The Grand Budapest Hotel. The distinctively Anderson-esque camera move is often used to change from one character to another with a huge 180-degree pan and mimics the mechanism of panoramic slides.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_other.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

links.description: The supreme 360-degree bullet shot was famously combined with slow motion, gun fights and time slice effects in The Matrix. To achieve the complex set-up, rigs of 360 still cameras were used to deliver lighting fast and seamless full 360-degree shots.

end.brief_description: Two young men, one rich, one middle class, both in love with the same woman, become US Air Corps fighter pilots and, eventually, heroic flying aces during World War I. Devoted best friends, their mutual love of the girl eventually threatens their bond.

constellations_other.name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals
constellations_other.description: The microphone was called the "terror of the studios" when sound films were introduced in the late 1920s, but after initial resistance Hollywood fully embraced the new technology.

links.description: Complex camera set ups aside, the simple yet effective push-in shot used in Wings achieved a similarly immersive impression, not only giving audiences short vignettes of other characters in the film but drawing them into the dizzying inner world of a drunken Jack Powell.

constellations_other.description: Painter and photographer Louis Le Prince was inspired to develop the technology to make animated pictures by the circular panoramic paintings of his friends. His films captured everyday life and alluded to his artistic vision for cinema.

links.description: Director Reed Morano used a similar shooting methodology on The Handmaid’s Tale. As a cinematographer herself, Morano had a specific idea for incorporating handheld camera work. This placed viewers as close as physically possible to Offred, offering greater insight into her emotional state.

results.name: Seeking asylum
results.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

key_work.title: Chauka, Please Tell Us The Time
key_work.brief_description: An urgent and powerful documentary, secretly filmed on a phone inside the Manus Island detention centre, where asylum seekers trying to reach Australia are indefinitely detained, by Iranian Kurdish journalist Behrouz Boochani, in collaboration with Dutch Iranian filmmaker Arash Kamali Sarvestani.

constellations_primary.name: Seeking asylum
constellations_primary.description: Chauka Please Tell Us the Time was covertly filmed on a smartphone inside the Manus Island Detention Centre and sent via WhatsApp.

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

start.title: Remain
start.brief_description: In her 2018 2-channel video work Remain, Iranian born Melbourne artist Hoda Afshar works with several of the refugees who remain on Manus Island, encouraging the men to ‘re-enact their narratives with their own bodies and [gives] them autonomy to narrate their own stories’.

constellations_other.name: Seeking asylum

end.title: Chasing Asylum
end.brief_description: Chasing Asylum tells the story of Australia’s cruel, inhumane treatment of asylum seekers and refugees, examining the human, political, financial and moral impact of current and previous policy.

start.title: Chauka, Please Tell Us The Time
start.brief_description: An urgent and powerful documentary, secretly filmed on a phone inside the Manus Island detention centre, where asylum seekers trying to reach Australia are indefinitely detained, by Iranian Kurdish journalist Behrouz Boochani, in collaboration with Dutch Iranian filmmaker Arash Kamali Sarvestani.

constellations_primary.name: Seeking asylum

constellations_other.name: Access to resistance
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

end.title: This Is Not a Film
end.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi and Mojtaba Mirtahmasb
end.brief_description: Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi makes a video diary with his phone in response to his government’s threats against him.

links.description: Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi was placed under house arrest and banned from filmmaking. The film was smuggled out of Iran in a cake, echoing Boochani’s covert sending of footage for Chauka out of Manus Island detention centre.

start.title: Airplane!
start.creator_credit: Howard W. Koch, Hunt Lowry, Jon Davison, Bill Hedge, Chris Casady, Jamie Shourt, Max W. Anderson, Peter Kuran, David Zucker, Jerry Zucker and Jim Abrahams
start.brief_description: Alcoholic pilot, Ted Striker has developed a fear of flying due to wartime trauma, but nevertheless boards a passenger jet in an attempt to woo back his stewardess girlfriend. Food poisoning decimates the passengers and crew, leaving it up to Striker to land the plane.

links.description: Airplane! was the product of trio Jerry Zucker, Jim Abrahams, and David Zucker who were known collectively in the business as ZAZ. They all went on to have successful solo filmmaking careers outside of their comedy films, with Jerry producing My Best Friend’s Wedding.

constellations_other.description: Women have been oppressed by patriarchal conventions and by men under the guise of the supernatural throughout history, but recent moving-image works are reframing these historical persecutions.

links.description: PJ Hogan wrote and directed this twist on Marry Poppins – Mental – which stars Toni Collette as a wild nanny who comes to shake up a family’s life. Hogan’s wife and longtime creative partner Jocelyn Moorhouse produced the film. Together they made The Dressmaker.

links.description: With a distinctly ‘of its time’ aesthetic, Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites players controlled actually looked like people. In the classic comedy film Airplane!, flight controllers are seen playing the game in the background of a scene.
